data.description: A Craft Talk / Author Q&A with Paul Harding will also be held on January 25th @ 4:30pm in the Campus Center West Boardroom on the UAlbany Uptown campus.   Paul Harding, Pulitzer Prize winning novelist 7:30 p.m.— Reading / Conversation, Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center Paul Harding’s new novel is This Other Eden (2023), based on the true story of a multiracial community that took refuge from intolerance on an island off the coast of Maine from 1792 to 1912. The novel presents the lives and experiences of a formerly enslaved Black man and his Irish wife, and multiple generations of their descendants and fellow islanders. Shortlisted for the 2023 Booker Prize, This Other Eden was also a finalist for the 2023 National Book Award for Fiction, and an NPR 2023 "Books We Love" Pick. A former student at the NYS Summer Writers Institute at Skidmore, Harding received the Pulitzer Prize for his 2009 first novel, Tinkers. Cosponsored by the Honors College at UAlbany, the English Department’s Creative Writing Program and Young Writers Project, and the Writing & Critical Inquiry (WCI) Program. For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center (UAlbany Uptown Campus)
data.name: Conversation with Paul Harding, Pulitzer Prize winning novelist

data.description: Join us in the MRC to learn about different small businesses in the capital region that are owned by people of color and get recommendations for food, beauty, and more!
data.name: Shop Local! Discovering Albany POC Businesses

data.description: FILM SCREENING January 26 (Friday) LACKAWANNA BLUES 7:00 p.m. — Screening, Page Hall, 135 Western Avenue, Downtown Campus (U.S., 2005, 95 minutes, color, Rated PG-13) Written and directed by George C. Wolfe. Adapted for the screen by Ruben Santiago-Hudson from his award-winning play, LACKAWANNA BLUES tells the story of a big-hearted woman, Rachel “Nanny” Crosby, who becomes a rock of stability for a collection of boarders, friends, and family members in a Rust Belt town in Western New York. Santiago-Hudson based the character on the woman who raised him after his own parents abandoned him. Meet Tony Award-winning actor, director, and playwright Ruben Santiago-Hudson at the annual Burian Lecture on Monday, Feb. 5th! For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.name: Film Screening: LACKAWANNA BLUES

data.description: WRITING ABOUT CANCER WITH HUMOR, WISDOM, AND TERROR January 31 (Wednesday) Elizabeth Benedict, essayist, novelist and writing coach 7:30 p.m.— Reading / Conversation with Robert Boyers, Multi-Purpose Room, Campus Center West Addition Author of the eternally popular how-to book, The Joy of Writing Sex: A Guide for Fiction Writers (1996), Elizabeth Benedict applies her talents to retelling the story of her recent encounter with cancer in Rewriting Illness: A View of My Own (2023). NPR’s Mara Liasson called it “startling, self-aware, and wickedly funny,” and Professor Kathy G. Niknejad, MD, of Harvard Medical School said, "Her surprisingly entertaining memoir should be required reading for every medical student, resident, and physician – an ideal teaching tool." Benedict’s 1985 novel, Slow Dancing, was a National Book Award Finalist. She has served on the fiction faculty of the New York State Summer Writers Institute since 1997. Cosponsored by UAlbany’s Women in Science and Health Network (WISH). For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Campus Center West Multipurpose Room (UAlbany Uptown Campus)
data.name: Reading / Conversation with Elizabeth Benedict

data.description: February 1 (Thursday) Sandra Guzmán, storyteller, editor and filmmaker 4:30 p.m.— Conversation / Q&A, Assembly Hall (2nd Floor), Campus Center Sandra Guzmán, Afro Indigenous storyteller and literary editor, presents her new anthology, Daughters of Latin America: An International Anthology of Writing by Latine Women (2023), a dazzling collection of essential works by 140 Latin American and indigenous writers— many of them translated into English for the first time. Kirkus Reviews called it, “A significant collection of Latine women’s voices across five centuries… A fresh, indispensable look at the wide, multicultural world of Latine women writers.” Guzmán also served as producer and interviewer for the Emmy-nominated documentary, TONI MORRISON: THE PIECES I AM, which the Writers Institute screened in 2019 to celebrate the life of UAlbany faculty member Toni Morrison (1931-2019). Cosponsored by UAlbany’s Department of Latin American, Caribbean, and U.S. Latino Studies and the Department of Women's, Gender and Sexuality Studies.  For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Assembly Hall (2nd floor), Campus Center, UAlbany Uptown Campus
data.name: Conversation with Sandra Guzmán, storyteller, editor and filmmaker

data.description: February 2 (Friday) THE SLEEPY TIME GAL 7:00 p.m. — Screening, Page Hall, 135 Western Avenue, Downtown Campus (U.S., 2001, 108 minutes, color, Rated R) Directed by Christopher Munch. Jacqueline Bisset, British actress who rose to Hollywood superstardom beginning in the 1960s, portrays an older woman who embarks on a search for the daughter she gave up for adoption in her youth, after becoming pregnant during an affair with a married man. Bisset regards this performance as the best of her career. Nominated for the Grand Jury Prize for Best Dramatic Feature at the Sundance Film Festival. Meet film legend Jacqueline Bisset, star of Francois Truffaut’s DAY FOR NIGHT and John Huston’s UNDER THE VOLCANO, at the 4th Annual Albany Film Festival on Saturday, April 6th, with her 2022 film LOREN & ROSE. For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.name: Film Screening: THE SLEEPY TIME GAL

data.description: BURIAN LECTURE ON LIFE IN THE PERFORMING ARTS February 5 (Monday) Ruben Santiago-Hudson, playwright, actor, director The 26th Annual Burian Lecture — 7:30 p.m., Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center Ruben Santiago-Hudson is a celebrated American playwright, actor, and director who has won major awards in all three categories. In 2021, he directed and starred in the Broadway production of his autobiographical play about growing up in a Rust Belt town outside Buffalo, Lackawanna Blues— marking the first time in Broadway history that an individual wrote, directed, and starred in a single play. He directed the 2022 Broadway production of Dominique Morisseau’s Skeleton Crew, which received four Tony nominations including Outstanding New Play. He also directed the 2017 Broadway production of August Wilson’s Jitney, which earned the Tony Award for Best Revival and five other Tony nominations. In 1996, he received the Tony Award as Featured Actor for his performance in August Wilson’s Seven Guitars. His 2021 screenplay adaptation of another Wilson play, Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom, received several Oscar nominations, winning two for costume design and makeup. Presented by the UAlbany Theatre Program and the Jarka and Grayce Burian Endowment in collaboration with the NYS Writers Institute. For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center (UAlbany Uptown Campus)
data.name: BURIAN LECTURE: Ruben Santiago-Hudson

data.description: A Craft Talk / Author Q&A with Aaliyah Bilal will also be held on February 8th @ 4:30pm in the Standish Room (3rd floor) of the Science Library, on the UAlbany Uptown campus.   Aaliyah Bilal, author of Temple Folk 7:30 p.m.— Reading / Conversation, Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center Aaliyah Bilal’s debut story collection, Temple Folk (2023), is a groundbreaking portrait of the lived experiences of Black Muslims—a community rarely featured in U.S. literature—as they grapple with the challenges of faith, family, and freedom in America. Bilal, who grew up in a Black Muslim family outside Washington, D.C., presents a diverse cast of flawed, heroic, and memorable characters. Edward P. Jones said, “Temple Folk is more than a special literary accomplishment, it is a gift of glorious songs…. this gift should be praised from as many rooftops as possible.” A finalist for the 2023 National Book Award for Fiction, it was named one of TIME magazines “100 Must-Read Books of 2023.” Cosponsored by the English Department’s Creative Writing Program and Young Writers Project.  For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center (UAlbany Uptown Campus)
data.name: Aaliyah Bilal - Reading / Conversation

data.description: February 16 (Friday) THE ARMOR OF LIGHT and Walt Disney’s 1928 animated short STEAMBOAT WILLIE 7:00 p.m. — Screening, Page Hall, 135 Western Avenue, Downtown Campus THE ARMOR OF LIGHT (U.S., 2015, 88 minutes, color, rated PG-13) is an acclaimed documentary directed by Abigail Disney— outspoken critic of American capitalism, philanthropist, filmmaker, and daughter of Walt Disney Company co-founder Roy O. Disney. The film tells the story of Evangelical minister Rob Schenck, a fixture on the political far right, who breaks with orthodoxy by questioning whether being pro-gun is consistent with being pro-life. The film earned the 2017 Emmy Award for Outstanding Social Issue Documentary. The screening will open with STEAMBOAT WILLIE (U.S., 1928, 7 minutes, b/w, rated G) A cultural artifact of extraordinary significance, the animated short that launched Mickey and Minnie Mouse loses its copyright protection and enters the public domain on January 1, 2024. Meet award-winning filmmaker and activist Abigail Disney at the 4th Annual Albany Film Festival on Saturday, April 6th, with her 2022 film about America’s culture of inequality, THE AMERICAN DREAM AND OTHER FAIRY TALES. For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.name: Film Screening: THE ARMOR OF LIGHT

data.description: TALES OF A DYING MALL IN UPSTATE NEW YORK February 22 (Thursday) Karin Lin-Greenberg, novelist and short story writer 4:30 p.m.— Conversation / Q&A, Assembly Hall (2nd Floor), Campus Center Karen Lin-Greenberg is the author of You Are Here (2023), a debut novel about the residents of a small Upstate New York town who must grapple with the impending closure of a once-bustling shopping mall. The novel appeared on numerous “Best of” lists throughout 2023, including Elle magazine’s “Best and Most Anticipated Books of 2023,” the Washington Post’s “10 Noteworthy Books for May,” and Oprah Daily’s “Best Books You Might Have Missed in 2023.” Publishers Weekly called it a “remarkable study of ordinary people’s extraordinary inner lives.” Lin-Greenberg’s 2013 story collection, Faulty Predictions, won the Flannery O'Connor Award in Short Fiction. She is Associate Professor of English at Siena College. Cosponsored by the Honors College at UAlbany, the English Department’s Creative Writing Program and Young Writers Project, and the Writing & Critical Inquiry (WCI) Program. For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Assembly Hall (2nd Floor), Campus Center, UAlbany Uptown Campus
data.name: Conversation with Karin Lin-Greenberg, novelist

data.description: FILM SCREENING February 23 (Friday) TURN EVERY PAGE: THE ADVENTURES OF ROBERT CARO AND ROBERT GOTTLIEB 7:00 p.m. — Screening, Page Hall, 135 Western Avenue, Downtown Campus (U.S., 2022, 112 minutes, Rated PG) Written and directed by Lizzie Gottlieb. Lizzie Gottlieb’s award-winning documentary explores the remarkable 50-year relationship between two literary legends, writer Robert Caro and his longtime editor Robert Gottlieb (the film director’s father who passed away in June 2023 at the age of 92). In the film, Caro was working to complete the final volume of his masterwork, The Years of Lyndon Johnson, for Gottlieb to edit. The New Yorker's Mary Norris called it “a rare window into a relationship that usually goes undocumented… the dance between editor and writer.” For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.name: Film Screening: TURN EVERY PAGE

data.description: William Wegman is a beloved American artist known throughout the world for photographs and videos that feature his Weimaraner dogs in a variety of costumes and poses. His work is held in the permanent collections of major museums, including the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the Smithsonian American Art Museum. The author of many books for children, Wegman is also the creator of numerous short segments featuring his dogs for Sesame Street. His new book is William Wegman: Writing by Artist (2022), his first collection to focus on his multifaceted and deeply funny relationship to language, spanning the early 1970s to the present. Created and produced by the New York State Writers Institute, University Art Museum, and UAlbany Performing Arts Center in collaboration with WAMC Northeast Public Radio, this series features leading figures from a variety of artistic disciplines in conversation with WAMC’s “Roundtable” host Joe Donahue about creative inspiration, craft, and career. ​Major support for The Creative Life is provided by the University at Albany Foundation and University Auxiliary Services. For more information, visit: www.albany.edu/arts/creative-life
data.location: Main Theatre, UAlbany Performing Arts Center
data.name: THE CREATIVE LIFE: A Conversation with artist William Wegman

data.description: THE STRANGE LAND BETWEEN FABLE AND REALITY February 29 (Thursday) Richard Mirabella, novelist and short story writer 4:30 p.m.— Conversation / Q&A, Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center Richard Mirabella is the author of the debut novel, Brother & Sister Enter the Forest (2023), a queer coming-of-age novel about a young man’s relationship with a violent older boyfriend—and how he and his sister survive a terrible crime. The book was named a New York Times Book Review Editors’ Choice, a Washington Post Noteworthy Book, and a Harper’s Bazaar Best New Book of 2023. The Vulture reviewer said, "Mirabella writes about the strange land between fable and reality…. Part fantastical horror, part road trip narrative… [it’s] an uncanny portrait of the lengths we go to protect the people we love." A member of the UAlbany community, Mirabella works for the University in the High School Program (UHS). Cosponsored by the English Department’s Creative Writing Program and Young Writers Project.  For more information, visit: https://www.nyswritersinstitute.org/
data.location: Recital Hall, UAlbany Performing Arts Center (UAlbany Uptown Campus)
data.name: Conversation with Richard Mirabella, novelist

data.description: From February 1st - March 1st, we celebrate the rich tapestry of African American history and culture through the lens of creativity and resilience. This Black History Month, the theme is "African Americans and the Arts", and we honor the indelible contributions of African Americans to the arts, weaving a vibrant narrative that transcends time.  Visit our toolkit to learn more!
data.name: Black History Month
organizationNames: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

data.description: Have you ever dreamed of hosting your own music radio show, talk show, or sportscast? Are you passionate about content creation, music production, or performing? At WCDB 90.9 FM - UAlbany's only student-run radio station, those dreams can become a reality!   Join us at CC 316, located on the third floor of the Campus Center. When you enter, take a right, and you'll find our friendly training directors waiting to introduce you to the exciting world of radio DJing. They'll provide expert guidance, share their experiences, and answer all your questions. It's not just a training session; it's the first step toward unleashing your creativity and connecting with other like-minded people!   Don't miss this chance to embark on your radio journey with us. WCDB 90.9 FM is not just a station; it's a family. Join us at our training show and discover the exciting possibilities that await!

data.description: Join the Atmospheric Science RGSO for the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences potluck on April 3rd at 6 pm in the ETEC Collabritorium. If you are interested in attending please bring a dish with any allergens clearly marked.
data.name: DAES Potluck

data.description: The 4th annual Albany Film Festival will include panel discussions with writers, screenwriters, critics, filmmakers and film industry professionals. Full-length and short film screenings of new work from aspiring student filmmakers to acclaimed directors will be shown, along with conversations and Q&As that encourage audience participation. Stay tuned to the Albany Film Festival website for the full schedule and more information: www.albanyfilmfestival.org Short film submissions are being accepted for consideration through January 31, 2024 - visit https://filmfreeway.com/AlbanyFilmFestival
data.name: NYS Writers Institute Albany Film Festival

data.description: Join the Atmospheric Science RGSO to celebrate Earth Day with an Earth Day Hike at the Albany Pine Bush. Our hike will take place on April 26th at 3 pm. Our hike will not be intense and is open to hikers of any level.
